Description: convex becoming plane or centrally depressed

Color_Change: turning deep green in ferrous sulfate

HABITAT: less abundant in winter and early spring

Description: convex becoming plane or slightly depressed
sometimes with a small pointed umbo

STALK: fading like the cap but more slowly
HABITAT: a-plot of cypresses mixed with oaks
EDIBILITY: gunner for partridges will not shoot rabbits
knowing toadstool-seeker will pass all others where H. miniatus abounds

CAP.1-5 (12) cm: broad, bluntly to sharply conical, sometimes expanding in age but usually retaining a pointed umbo
CAP.surface: smooth, dry to moist or slightly viscid, sometimes red but more often orange, yellow, or olive-yellow

GILLS.description: adnexed or free, thick, broad, soft, waxy
GILLS.color: usually whitish but sometimes tinged yellow, soon becoming grayish and finally black

STALK.description: equal, not viscid or only slightly so, usually striate and/or twisted, hollow in age and easily splitting
STALK.color: pallid to yellow, olive-yellow, orange, or red, with a whitish to gray base, but turning gray or black when handled or in age

HABITAT: Solitary to scattered or gregarious on ground in damp places (usually in woods); widely distributed and very common, but rarely fruiting in large numbers. It is known from a wide variety of habitats in North America, but in our area shows a pro-nounced preference for redwood and cypress. It fruits in the fall and winter and, along with H. acutoconica, is usually the first of the brightly colored waxy caps to appear. Bob Winter says it often grows on lawns in Fresno, California.
EDIBILITY: Not recommended. It was once considered poisonous, perhaps due to its blackening qualities, but also because four deaths in China were (mistakenly?) attributed to it. Now it's generally regarded as harmless, but Larry Stickney, chef eXlra ordina ire, meandering mainstay of the Mycological Society of San Francisco, and an inimitable mushroom-loving marvel of a man, says it "elicited an odd sensation of lightheadedness and numbness" when he tried it. At any rate, it hardly seems worth experimenting with such a thin-fleshed, watery, tasteless morsel.

CAP: expanding somewhat but retaining a pointed umbo
coral-pink to pink to salmon when young (rarely tinged lavender)
paler (or pinker or oranger, sometimes with whitish areas) in age
margin often splitting at maturity and sometimes uplifted
GILLS: adnate to adnexed or even free
STALK: white or tinged pinkish (or rarely lavender)
HABITAT: found only twice in our area

STALK: discoloring slightly yellowish or pinkish in age
HABITAT: common fall and winter Hygrophorus of oak-madrone woodlands
fruits in late summer and fall under pinyon pine (New Mexico)
EDIBILITY: sliminess (see comments on edibility of H. sordidus)

HABITAT: fruits with live oak in the fall and winter

Authority_opinion: best of the family for the table

Luen_Miller: Not as good as H. sordidus

Description: pinker or paler at the margin

Surface: dry to tacky but not truly viscid
Upper_Part: conspicuously punctate (with tiny whitish scurfy scales or tufts that darken to reddish-brown when dried or in age, and turn yellow-orange in KG H)

HABITAT: Scattered or in groups on ground under conifers
widely distributed but erratic in its fruiting habits
It does not occur in our area (probably due to the absence of spruce)
but [ have seen large fruitings in December with Sitka spruce in northern California
and in August with Engelmann spruce in the Southwest.
EDIBILITY: Some variants are said to have a 'turpentine-like taste,'
but I cannot vouch for the accuracy of this comparison

CAP: obtuse to convex becoming broadly convex or plane
the margin usually paler or whitish.
GILLS: usually decurrent but varying to adnate
HABITAT: Widely scattered to gregarious under conifers
known only from the Pacific Northwest and northern California
very common at times in the fall and early winter.

CAP.Shape: convex to plane or with margin uplifted
CAP.Color: dull gray to ashy-gray, brownish-gray, or at times grayish-olive

GILLS.Color: white or sometimes grayish in age

HABITAT: Scattered to gregarious under conifers, widely distributed and fairly common in cool weather, but rather infrequent in our area. It is partial to spruce, but is associated locally with Douglas-fir (probably because there isn't any spruce).

EDIBILITY.Note: It is unfortunate that it doesn't taste like it smells.
